content:
First question: Let fff and ggg be two parallel 1-morphisms in a quasicategory. Then fff is homotopic to ggg if and only if ggg is homotopic to fff. (Recall: fff is homotopic to ggg if there is a 2-morphism/homotopy from fff to ggg.) Consider your favorite proof of that fact. Extract from that proof a map
(−)−1 ⁣:{homotopies from f to g}→{homotopies from g to f},σ↦σ−1.(-)^{-1}\colon \{\text{homotopies from }f\text{ to }g\}\to\{\text{homotopies from }g\text{ to }f\}, \sigma\mapsto \sigma^{-1}.(−)−1:{homotopies from f to g}→{homotopies from g to f},σ↦σ−1.
Is that map a bijection "on the nose" in the sense that (σ−1)−1(\sigma^{-1})^{-1}(σ−1)−1 is equal to σ\sigmaσ or only up to some form of equivalence of homotopies? (How to define that notion of "equivalence" of homotopies?)

On the one hand, since this is "higher category theory" I would expect the answer to be "up to equivalence". On the other hand, if fff and ggg are paths in a space with the same endpoints, then there is an on-the-nose bijection between homotopies from fff to ggg and homotopies from ggg to fff: given a homotopy H ⁣:[0,1]2→XH\colon [0,1]^2\to XH:[0,1]2→X from fff to ggg, the construction (x,t)↦H(x,1−t)(x,t)\mapsto H(x, 1-t)(x,t)↦H(x,1−t) defines a homotopy H−1H^{-1}H−1 from ggg to fff (and vice versa). And then we have (H−1)−1=H(H^{-1})^{-1}=H(H−1)−1=H on the nose.

Second question: One can show that fff is homotopic to ggg in a quasicategory C\mathcal CC if and only if fff is homotopic to ggg in Cop\mathcal C^{\mathrm{op}}Cop. Extract from the proof of that fact a map
{homotopies from f to g in C}→{homotopies from f to g in Cop}.\{\text{homotopies from }f\text{ to }g\text{ in }\mathcal C\}\to\{\text{homotopies from }f\text{ to }g\text{ in }\mathcal C^{\mathrm{op}}\}.{homotopies from f to g in C}→{homotopies from f to g in Cop}.
Is that map a bijection on the nose, only up to equivalence, or none of that?

So there are a couple issues with the premises of the question. The first one is that there is a map to be extracted from the proof of the fact. There isn't really one because the proof invokes the hypothesis that the input is a quasicategory to choose a solution to some filling problem, and there's no specified way to make this choice.

The second one is that there isn't even an "inverse-ness" relation between σ\sigmaσ and σ−1\sigma^{-1}σ−1, because in order for σ−1\sigma^{-1}σ−1 to be an inverse to σ\sigmaσ you also have to say how it is an inverse. (This already happens at the level of 1-morphisms as well: an inverse of f:x→yf : x \to yf:x→y is g:y→xg : y \to xg:y→x together with some additional data; at a minimum, a 2-morphism α:gf≃1\alpha : gf \simeq 1α:gf≃1.)

The better way to think about this kind of question is to consider a space (i.e. simplicial set) of homotopies, say H(f,g)H(f,g)H(f,g), whose 0-simplices we can presumably arrange to be your 2-simplices σ:f→g\sigma : f \to gσ:f→g, and also a space I(f,g)I(f,g)I(f,g) consisting of triples σ:f→g\sigma : f \to gσ:f→g, τ:g→f\tau : g \to fτ:g→f, and coherence data that says that σ\sigmaσ and τ\tauτ are inverse. Then construct a zigzag

H(f,g)←p1I(f,g)→p2H(g,f)H(f,g) \xleftarrow{p_1} I(f,g) \xrightarrow{p_2} H(g,f)H(f,g)p1​​I(f,g)p2​​H(g,f)

where p1p_1p1​ and p2p_2p2​ remember just σ\sigmaσ, respectively τ\tauτ.

One then shows that p1p_1p1​ and p2p_2p2​ are acyclic Kan fibrations so that, if we want, we could choose a section s1s_1s1​ of p1p_1p1​ and consider the composite

H(f,g)→s1I(f,g)→p2H(g,f)H(f,g) \xrightarrow{s_1} I(f,g) \xrightarrow{p_2} H(g,f)H(f,g)s1​​I(f,g)p2​​H(g,f)

as a choice of your function "(−)−1(-)^{-1}(−)−1". However, there is nothing canonical about this choice. The well-determined notion is the span.

Thanks!
But I guess one can define maps on equivalence classes:

  • (−)−1 ⁣:{homotopies from f to g in C}/≃→{homotopies from g to f in C}/≃(-)^{-1}\colon \{\text{homotopies from }f\text{ to }g\text{ in }\mathcal C\}/\mathord{\simeq}\to\{\text{homotopies from }g\text{ to }f\text{ in }\mathcal C\}/\mathord{\simeq}(−)−1:{homotopies from f to g in C}/≃→{homotopies from g to f in C}/≃ and
  • (−)op ⁣:{homotopies from f to g in C}/≃→{homotopies from f to g in Cop}/≃(-)^{\mathrm{op}}\colon\{\text{homotopies from }f\text{ to }g\text{ in }\mathcal C\}/\mathord{\simeq}\to\{\text{homotopies from }f\text{ to }g\text{ in }\mathcal C^{\mathrm{op}}\}/\mathord{\simeq}(−)op:{homotopies from f to g in C}/≃→{homotopies from f to g in Cop}/≃.

Are both of these maps (−)−1(-)^{-1}(−)−1 and (−)op(-)^{\mathrm{op}}(−)op bijections?

Also, can one construct an ∞\infty∞-category C\mathcal CC in which there isn't a bijection
{homotopies from f to g in C}≅{homotopies from g to f in C}\{\text{homotopies from }f\text{ to }g\text{ in }\mathcal C\}\cong\{\text{homotopies from }g\text{ to }f\text{ in }\mathcal C\}{homotopies from f to g in C}≅{homotopies from g to f in C}
on the nose? As I said, for singular simplicial sets there should be such a bijection on the nose. That question is a bit artificial, but I'm curious nevertheless. (Same question in the other situation.)

Or are these questions again ill-defined? Then let me put it this way: Is the datum of a homotopy from fff to ggg in C\mathcal CC in some sense equivalent to the datum of a homotopy from ggg to fff in C\mathcal CC? Also, is the datum of a homotopy from fff to ggg in Cop\mathcal C^\mathrm{op}Cop in some sense equivalent to the datum of a homotopy from fff to ggg in C\mathcal CC? If yes, in which sense? If no, why not?
